title.value: On the incompatibility of accuracy and equal opportunity
title.justification: This is the title provided in the initial metadata and reiterated in the content of the paper.
title.quote: On the incompatibility of accuracy and equal opportunity

extractions.description: In this paper, the authors explore the theoretical boundaries and limitations when trying to achieve both accuracy and equal opportunity (EO) in machine learning classification tasks. They present geometric interpretations and mathematical proofs to show the incompatibility between EO and non-trivial accuracy in certain probabilistic data distributions. The results are verified through algorithmic implementations and examples based on both synthetic and real datasets.

type.justification: The paper primarily focuses on theoretical analysis and mathematical proofs to make its arguments regarding the incompatibility between accuracy and equal opportunity.
type.quote: The analysis of this paper is mostly theoretical and is limited to the notion of equal opportunity, hence to distributions with binary targets and binary sensitive attributes.

name.justification: The primary research area of the paper is focused on fairness, specifically equal opportunity, in machine learning classification tasks.
name.quote: One such definition of fairness is equal opportunity [13], which is one of the most common group notions of fairness along with disparate impact, demographic parity, and equalized odds [21]

name.justification: The paper includes extensive theoretical analysis and mathematical proofs.
name.quote: The analysis of this paper is mostly theoretical and is limited to the notion of equal opportunity, hence to distributions with binary targets and binary sensitive attributes.

name.justification: The paper frequently references the Bayes classifier as part of its theoretical framework.
name.quote: We prove that for certain distributions, the Bayes classifier does not satisfy EO. As a consequence, in these cases, EO can only be achieved by trading-off some accuracy.

is_contributed.justification: The Bayes classifier is a well-known model and was not introduced by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We prove that for certain distributions, the Bayes classifier does not satisfy EO. As a consequence, in these cases, EO can only be achieved by trading-off some accuracy.

is_executed.justification: The Bayes classifier is discussed in theory; actual execution details on hardware are not mentioned.
is_executed.quote: Satisfying equal opportunity typically requires a probabilistic predictor [13], but also because it has a practical justification.

is_compared.justification: The performance of the Bayes classifier is compared within the theoretical framework proposed by the authors.
is_compared.quote: We prove that for certain distributions, the Bayes classifier does not satisfy EO.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper where the Bayes classifier is originally discussed.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Fukunaga, K. (2013). Introduction to statistical pattern recognition. Elsevier.

name.justification: The paper includes an example based on a modified version of the Adult dataset to illustrate the theoretical results.
name.quote: A preliminary and partial version of this paper appeared in the proceedings of AAAI 2022 [22]. In this document, we extend the AAAI-2022 version by studying the Pareto-optimal boundary (Section 7), the necessary and sufficient conditions (Theorem 10) that characterize the impossibility between equal opportunity and non-trivial accuracy, and a practical example based on the Adult dataset (Figure 9).
